story: WithLabour losing seats to the SNP in Scotland and to the Conservatives in England, Mr Leonard said his partyrsquos message had failed to break through against the ldquodin of Brexit and the debate over whether there should be a second independence referendum.He said Labour had ldquotried to talkabout what we felt were important things, as he said he regretted deeply that the party had lost MPs such as Danielle Rowley to the SNP in Midlothian."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Jeremy Corbyn says he will not lead the Labour Party into another election","description": "Jeremy Corbyn says he will not lead the Labour Party into another election","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media BiTOgEVC poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests BiTOgEVC.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": :General election : How every constituency has voted in ScotlandLabourrsquos Ged Killen also lost his Rutherglen and Hamilton West seat to the SNP, while former Scottish justice secretary Kenny MacAskill won the East Lothian constituency from Martin Whitfield.Mr Leonard told BBC Scotland: ldquoThese are deeply disappointing results.While he said he is sorry for those candidates who have lost out, he added: ldquoMore than that I am sorry for all those kids in all those families who are going to live for another five years in poverty when we had a chance in this election to make a real dference to peoplersquos lives.ldquoI think there is no doubt we said we wanted to get through the din of Brexit and the constitutional issue in Scotland and I just donrsquot think we were able to do that sufficiently and effectively enough.ldquoWe need to reflect on that and learn the lessons from that.SNP WIN! Thats !@KennyMacAskill wins East Lothian for the SNP. #GE #SNPWin pic oWZANICimdash The SNP | VOTE SNP #######December , He said Labour had attempted to campaign on key issues such as the ldquorise in poverty and inequality, the squeeze on public services like the National Health Service that we have experienced over the last decade.Mr Leonard said his party is ldquogoing to need to have a look at what we said about Brexit, what we said about the whole constitutional question in Scotland.:Jo Swinson loses seat and Jeremy Corbyn steps down as SNP make large gainsBut he added: ldquoI donrsquot think it is so simple as to sayonly we had an absolutely cast iron message, that would have made all of the dference.ldquoBecause parties that have stood in this election with what people described as clear, cast iron, absolutist positions have also been swept aside by the SNP juggernaut.

title: election-worry-democracy
story: Being honest is less important than being visibleDid it say this on the white board in Dominic Cummingsrsquo office  It might as well have done.Politicians have never been saints, but systematic dishonesty from the very top of a party is an innovation, and a dangerous one.Boris Johnson was a proven liar before the campaign and where he led, the Tory campaign followed, with a doctored video of the shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer plastered all over social media and a brazen attempt by Conservative central office to hoodwink people on Twitter by posing as a fact-checking organisation.Like complacent old colonials faced with complaining locals, senior Tories casually batted away criticism of it all. The party even briefed journalists earlier this week that a Tory aide had been punched by a Labour activist, which was a big fat lie served up with an extra helping of tripe.The Tories may not have been the only offenders ndash the Lib Dems used misleading bar charts on campaign literature and the SNP had to withdraw a leaflet because of a  claim about Jo Swinson ndash but the Conservativesrsquo flagrancy has been of a dferent order, apparently driven by the cynical logic that getting found out is worth it to buy extra airtime during the ensuing row.We should all worry for our democracy. A rot has set in. :Conservatives win majority in general election as SNP vote surgesIt is an age of political pygmiesAll main UK party leaders had substantial negative approval ratings as polling opened and a YouGov survey on Wednesday found that two thirds of voters were unenthusiastic about the election.Who can blame them  Jeremy Corbynrsquos refusal to apologise in his Andrew Neil interview for his handling of anti-Semitism, and his feeble lie about the Queenrsquos Speech, were head-in-hands moments. But the spectacle of politicians hurling blame at each other following the death of Jack Merritt and Saskia Jones in the London terrorist attack, was the nadir of a grim campaign. The Conservatives behaved like greyhounds out of the traps as soon as the period of campaigning purdah expired with their attempts to blame Labour .Voters feel they deserve better. Theyrsquod be right.Broadcasters have to get better at handling politiciansWhen Boris Johnson, the aforementioned serial liar, started refusing to appear on television, broadcasters were put on the spot. Channel  stood up for themselves and the democratic process by replacing Mr Johnson with an ice sculpture during their debate on climate change, and then facing down the Tories when they complainedto Ofcom.The BBC however has struggled to get it right. Like ITV, they failed to get a firm commitment from Mr Johnson at the outset of the campaign to a one-to-one interview with Mr Neil. Mr Neil telling viewers the questions he would have asked Mr Johnson was effective, but not enough to reset the imbalance after other party leaders had undergone a proper interview.On Monday night ndash the day Mr Johnson took a reporterrsquos phone off him to avoid looking at the picture of a four-year-old left for hours on the floor of Leeds General Hospital ndash the Tories refused to put anyone on Newsnight, so Labour frontbencher Barry Gardiner went on alone. The Tories were then rewarded for not turning up when, in spite of Mr Johnsonrsquos dire performance that day, the interview by Emily Maitlis became an attack on Jeremy Corbyn for not visiting enough hospitals. How can it be right to let the no-shows off and turn all the heat on those who submit to scrutiny Politicians are boldly testing the boundaries of the acceptable. Broadcasters must push back harder.:General election : How every constituency has voted in ScotlandOn Monday night ndash the day Mr Johnson took a reporters phone off him to avoid looking at the picture of a four-year-old left on the floor of Leeds General Hospital ndash the Tories refused to put anyone on Newsnight, so Labour frontbencher Barry Gardiner went on alone. The Tories were then rewarded for not turning up when, in spite of Mr Johnsons dire performance that day, the interview by Emily Maitlis became an attack on Jeremy Corbyn for not visiting enough hospitals. How can it be right to let the no-shows off and turn all the heat on those who submit to scrutiny Politicians are boldly testing the boundaries of the acceptable. Broadcasters must push back harder.Boris Johnson is not a great campaignerHe was seen as the antithesis of Theresa May but one of the campaignrsquos surprises has been the uncanny similarity between Mr Johnson and the Maybot.During his encounters with the public, Mr Johnson has at times seemed just as awkward and tongue-tied and the bonhomie as forced.He seems to be regarded by his own side as even more of a liability in interviews.Many Conservative MPs regard him as a charlatan, but voted for him as leader because of his fabled campaigning skills.Itrsquos lucky for them that the Brexit Party more or less collapsed itself at the outset of the campaign to help the Tories, because itrsquos very unlikely Mr Johnson would have achieved those poll ratings otherwise.The two-party system is still robustThe Liberal Democrats were on  per cent in the polls in September and Jo Swinson dared to dream of being the next Prime Minister.But Ms Swinsonrsquos policy of revoking Article  was an unhelpful distraction and Ms Swinson herself went down poorly with voters. This decline, coupled with the usual suffocating squeeze on the Lib Dems, turned the partyrsquos dreams to dust.The SNP may have managed to break the mould in Scotland but the Lib Dems will have to regroup and rethinkthe two-party system is to be prised open.Christmas elections are a bad ideaA spoof ad of Love Actually must have seemed like a wizard ruse to the Tories.The rest of us thought ldquoOh God, no.The idea of an ingratiating Mr Johnson using one the most saccharine of British movies as a vehicle to bash us over the head with his misleading Brexit policy, induced the sort of dyspeptic feeling normally associated with downing an ill-advised gingerbread latte at speed while Christmas shopping.And it wasnrsquot good. Mr Johnson was wisely prevented from speaking during the adbut he still managed to come over as glib and insincere in writing.Jeremy Corbynrsquos Mean Tweets fireside chat, reading out offensive remarks about himself on social media, was more easygoing and less forced, though he clearly hasnrsquot been reading the same Twitter feeds as methatrsquos the worst he could come up with.Thank God the campaign ended before they sullied any more of our shared festive heritage.If Santa thinks Brexit is a good idea, we donrsquot want to know.

title: herald-diary-great-mistooks-time
story: ldquoMISTAKES, wersquove made a fewhellip thatrsquos the tearful tune certain politicians will be warbling in woe this weekend. Either that, or the likes of Jeremy Corbyn and Jo Swinson will be blaming the media for their precipitous fall from grace. Diary Corner we view blaming the media as the new version of: ldquoIt wisnae me! A big boy done it anrsquo ran awayhellip Of course, everybody makes mistakes. Even Diary readers. With that in mind wersquove decided to look back at a few classic stories from our archive, focusing on mistakes big and small. For instance, there was the schoolchild who was asked by a science teacher to explain what was inertia. Came the reply: ldquoTroon and Prestwick.Hoodwinked by songA BRIDE-TO-BE, after much thought, chose to proceed to the alter to the tune from the film Robin Hood, Prince of Thieves. This tune, which you have probably heard many times, is the romantic Everything I Do, I Do It For You by Bryan Adams. The person in charge of the wedding music, being of a dferent generation, got it slightly wrong. The bride was not impressed to be confronted by the strains of an earlier hitwith the stirring but decidedly unromantic lyrics: ldquoRobin Hood, Robin Hood riding through the glenhellipSlope-off SaturdaySADLY the state of wedded bliss can also turn out to be a mistake, leading to painful regrets. A reader once overheard a woman complaining long and loud to her female friend about her marriage. Trying to be supportive, her pal said: ldquoYes, I suppose the magic just isnrsquot there after a while, to which her dispirited friend snapped back: ldquoOh, therersquos still magic. Every Saturday night he disappears.Bungling boffinA PROFESSOR of neurosurgery at Glasgow University was booked to give a talk to staff and clients at a day centre in Shettleston on the topic of memory loss and lack of concentration. He failed to turn up because he had forgotten to put the engagement in the diary.Iron manHeres a great story former Diarist Ken Smith gleaned from social media, and that we in turn gleaned from his new book, The Herald Diary: A Quacking Good Read.Ken relates an internet conversation where people were discussing the most embarrassing ways they had hurt themselves. One boneheaded bloke piped up: ldquoBroke four ribs while ironing the curtains. Which at first might seem a mysterious way to get injured, until the bloke added: ldquoThey were still hanging, and it was am, and I was drunk, so it was mostly on me.Load of old lsquotoshA GLASGOW musician once told us he found a pair of tarnished candlesticks in a bin in Dennistoun. He gave them as a present to a pal. Later he went to visit this pal in his new, and very splendid, country retreat. ldquoItrsquos all thanks to you, explained the pal. ldquoThose candlesticks were Charles Rennie Mackintosh and became very valuable. In fact, we bought this house with the money they fetched.Salad daysWE end our run of stories about inglorious mistakes with a tale of mistaken identity, told to us by reader Stanley Miller. ldquoI met this girl at a vegan restaurant who said she knew me, says Stan, before adding: ldquoBut I never met herbivore.

title: sturgeon-defeated-tories-cant-stand-way-indyref2
story: Pressing for Indyref after the SNP won  per cent of Scottish seats in the general election, the First Minister delivered the message direct on live TV.She announced the Scottish Government would next week publish ldquothe detailed democratic case for giving Holyrood the power to hold another referendum in .She is expected to send a separate request for that power, under Section  of the  Scotland Act, to the Prime Minister by the end of the year.Mr Johnson has already said he will refuse it, and Ms Sturgeon has yet to say what she will dohe does.The SNP won  of Scotlandrsquos  seats on Thursday, an improvement of  on .:General election : How every constituency has voted in ScotlandIt also increased its share of the vote from . to %, and gained , votes, taking its total to .million.The Scottish Tories, whose campaign was based on opposing Indyref, lost seven of their  MPs, and saw their vote share fall from to . to .% and their vote total fall , to ,.Speaking at Our Dynamic Earth in Edinburgh, Ms Sturgeon described the ldquostunning result as a watershed that ldquorenews, reinforces and strengthens the mandate for Indyref.The First Minister said: ldquoThis is not about asking Boris Johnson or any other Westminster politician for permission. It is an assertion of the democratic right of the people of Scotland to determine their own future."She added: ldquoIt is clear that that the kind of future desired by the majority in Scotland is dferent to that chosen by the rest of the UK. Scotland has rejected Boris Johnson and the Tories and, yet again, we have said no to Brexit.She said it was ldquoclear beyond any doubt that Scotland did not want Brexit and it was ldquotime for Boris Johnson to start listening.She said: ldquoI accept - regretfully - that he has a mandate for Brexit in England. But he has no mandate whatsoever to take Scotland out of the EU.ldquoIf he presses ahead he will drive a coach and horses through the very idea that is supposed to underpin the UK ndash the idea that this union is a partnership of equal nations.:Nicola Sturgeon: Boris Johnson does not have a mandate to take Scotland out of the EUShe acknowledged not all those voted SNP supported independence, but she hoped there was ldquoa point of unity on it being for Scotland to decide its future, not Westminster.She said: ldquoIt is not a decision for any Westminster Prime Minister - and certainly not for one who suffered a crushing defeat in Scotland last night.The Tories fought the campaign in Scotland on a single issue.ldquoThey spoke about nothing . They bombarded people in Scotland with the same relentless message day after day and night after night.ldquoThey said a vote for them was a vote to deny people in Scotland the right to decide our own future. They said it was a vote to reject an independence referendum:ldquoWell, yesterday, the people of Scotland rejected the Tories instead.She concluded: ldquoGiven the verdict of the people of Scotland last night, the Scottish Government will next week publish the detailed democratic case for a transfer of power to enable a referendum to be put beyond legal challenge.ldquoTo the Prime Minister let me be clear. This is not simply a demand that I or the SNP are making. It is the right of the people of Scotland ndash and you as the leader of a defeated party in Scotland have no right to stand in the way.ldquoThe people of Scotland have spoken ndash it is time to decide our own future.She refused to take questions from the media.AskedMr Johnson should grant a Section  order, Scottish Secretary Alister Jack said: "No, wersquove said it was once-in-a-generation and that generation isnrsquot past yet, and I would still maintain morepeople will have cast votes in Scotland for Unionist parties than will have cast votes for the SNP.Mr Jack last month said an SNP majority win at Holyrood in  would constitute a "democratic mandate".The Scottish Greens said Ms Sturgeon should request a Section  order immediately.:Jackson Carlaw: Scottish Tories had remarkable result despite losing most MPsCo-leader Lorna Slater said: ldquoA Conservative majority is terrible news for the poor and disenfranchised, for disabled people, for EU citizens and refugees, but we canrsquot lose hope.ldquoWe can still resist Boris Johnsonrsquos deregulated race to the bottom, which promises to rip up our rights and environmental protections and sell off our NHS. The Scottish Greens will continue the fight for equality and the planet.ldquoBut the case for independence has never been clearer. Given it was all the Scottish Conservatives talked about in this election, Boris Johnson has no political capital to refuse a section  order now. The longer he waits, the louder the clamour will become.ldquoNicola Surgeon should seek one immediately, especially since the Scottish Parliament already instructed her to do so in .ldquoBut the case for independence must be based on an alternative vision from Tory Britain. It must have equality, localism and building a new sustainable future at its heart.Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, denied the election result was a mandate for a second independence referendum.She said: ldquoBefore the votes were counted, the SNP was clear it was asking for votes to stop Brexit and to stop the Tories. It is dishonest of Nicola Sturgeon to now try and argue that votes cast on this basis give her a mandate for another referendum.ldquoDespite the seats won, a majority of people in Scotland, %, voted for pro-UK parties. ldquoWhat we need now is for the majority of people throughout Scotland, from all walks of le, who believe that our future is stronger in the UK, to come together in order to reject the isive nationalism that has become the scourge of Scotland.

title: scottish-tory-leader-vows-stand-firmly-indyref2-face-snp-push
story: Jackson Carlaw made the comments as he insisted his party had secured a ldquoremarkable result in the general election ndash despite losing seven MPs north of the Border.Mr Carlaw said he has already spoken to Boris Johnson to congratulate him on his victory and insisted the Prime Minister would put ldquostrengthening the Union at the heart of his agenda.It came as Nicola Sturgeon told Mr Johnson he is ldquothe leader of a defeated party in Scotland and so has no right to stand in the way of a second independence referendum.:Sturgeon: defeated Tories cant stand in way of IndyrefThe First Minister ndash whose party won  per cent of Scotlandrsquos seats ndash announced she would next week publish ldquothe detailed democratic case for giving Holyrood the power to hold another referendum in .Speaking in Glasgow, Mr Carlaw said: ldquoAt the beginning of this campaign, there were confident predictions that we would have electoral wipeout in Scotland at this election.""@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Jackson Carlow holds post-election press conference","description": "Scottish Conservative Leader Jackson Carlow held a post-election press conference at the Crowne Plaza Hotel, Glasgow today.    Kirsty Anderson Herald and Times","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media ajTIwMXX poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests ajTIwMXX.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": He said: ldquoBy the end the predictions had changed, and we were told we might hold on to all of them.ldquoSo there is of course no way of getting round the fact that from  to six MPs in Scotland is a disappointment to us.ldquoBut the numbers show that having made our breakthrough in  and , we have no cemented our position as Scotlandrsquos main opposition party to the SNP.ldquoWinning nearly , votes across the country is a fantastic achievement.ldquoUnlike Labour, last night we largely maintained our share of the vote, with our second best showing since .ldquoAnd most importantly of all, we will now be part of a majority Conservative government at Westminster. This is good news for Scotland.The interim Scottish Tory leader said he spoke to Mr Johnson on Friday afternoon ldquoto discuss his plans, and I congratulated him on the result across the whole of the UK, which was quite remarkable.He added: ldquoAnd Irsquom confident that next week, he will present a unying agenda as he begins work that will put strengthening of the Union at its heart, making sure that our Union of four nations ndash Scotland, England, Wales and Northern Ireland ndash works for all its people, and give us all the security and prosperity we want.ldquoNow in the last hour I have already heard Nicola Sturgeon claim that last nightrsquos result is a mandate for a second referendum on independence.ldquoOf course, up until pm last night that was not the story told by the SNP ndash it was, they said, about stopping Brexit and blocking Boris.:Nicola Sturgeon: Boris Johnson does not have a mandate to take Scotland out of the EUldquoNonetheless the SNP has reverted to form and decided to take the vote it won yesterday as a free pass for a referendum next year.ldquoIrsquom clear her plan would take us back to more ision and chaos.ldquoImagine, just as the rest of the UK is now set to move on and put constitutional ision and referendums behind it, Scotland would remain stuck ndash the one part of this country still trapped in the isive arguments of the past, unable to focus on the challenges of the future.ldquoSo today I want to reassure the people, the , people who gave us their support yesterday, that we still stand firmly as before, and say to them directly: you voted Scottish Conservative and Unionist yesterday for us to stop that referendum. We will not let you down.ldquoThe  referendum was a once in a generation event. It should be respected as such.ldquoThe Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party will be the party to do so.Mr Carlaw said: ldquoI hope to sit down with the Prime Minister and have a full discussion in early course about how as Minister of the Union ndash the position he adopted, which of course because of the general election hersquos not had much time to amply and flesh out ndash and as a UK government we will do more to promote the Union across the whole of the UK but particularly here in Scotland.Asked by The Herald whether he took responsibility for the Tory vote share falling in Scotland, while it rose across the UK, he said: ldquoI donrsquot accept that.ldquoI donrsquot actually think Scotland was so terribly dferent from the rest of the UK yesterday.ldquoThe story across the whole of the UK was the collapse of the Labour Party.ldquoIn the north-east of England, that collapse broke in favour of the Brexit Party.ldquoHere in Scotland it broke in favour of the SNP. In seats across Scotland our vote went up in some seats it went down.ldquoBut it was our second best result since , when we obtained, I think, . per cent of the vote ndash this time ..ldquoSo I still think this is a remarkable result. If this was repeated at the election in  there would be considerably more Conservative MSPs in the Scottish Parliament.He said the collapse in Labourrsquos vote was far greater than people anticipated.:Jeremy Corbyn confirms he will stand down in early He added: ldquoI thought our people in all the seats put up a magnicent fight and Irsquom disappointed, as I say, that we lost colleagues.ldquoBut Irsquom not downhearted about the performance of the Scottish Conservatives in terms of the vote that we achieved yesterday in the circumstances of the campaign.Askedhe will be a candidate in a future election to become the permanent leader of the Scottish Tories, Mr Carlaw said: ldquoIrsquove enjoyed this campaign.ldquoI believe that I have helped bring clarity and focus to it. I believe that therersquos more that I can offer the Scottish Conservatives going forward.ldquoBut thatrsquos not the immediate discussion that we need to have.

title: inverness-based-gaelic-language-organisation-criticised-auditor-general-scotland
story: Caroline Gardner has raised several concerns about the management of Bord na Gaidhlig, from ineffective leadership to poor relationships and organisational culture.Created in , its role is to promote the use of Gaelic across Scotland and to advise the Scottish Government about issues relating to the language.The Inverness-based Bord employs  staff and is funded by Scottish Government grants, with a net expenditure in the last year of pound. million.:Scottish Gaelic Duolingo app accrues , users in just one weekIn her report looking into the organisations governance, Ms Gardner said: "Gaelic is an important part of Scotlands culture."But all public bodies, irrespective of their size, must demonstrate clear and effective governance and make key decisions in an open and transparent way."The Bords leadership team and board must deliver signicant improvements in the issues raised to establish the trust and confidence of staff and stakeholders, including the Parliament and the public."Warning of a "lack of confidence and a culture of mistrust throughout the organisation" because of the lack of leadership, the report also expressed concern that all board and committee meetings were held in private - indicating a wider problem of "a lack of openness and transparency in decision-making".:Concern after court rules attending Gaelic school lsquonot in girlrsquos best interestsrsquoResponding to the report, the convener of the Scottish Parliaments Public Audit Committee Jenny Marra said: "Time and again we hear of poor leadership and poor governance in public bodies, and Bord na Gaidhlig is no dferent according to Audit Scotland."If Bord na Gaidhlig is to succeed in its mission to safeguard and promote the Gaelic language then substantive improvement will be required."The Public Audit committee will want a clear understanding of how they got to this point and how they plan to turn it around."

title: boris-bulldozer-labours-red-wall-dismantled-brick-brick
story: And, of course, it was the Conservative leader bulldozing his way through Labourrsquos ldquored wall from the Midlands to northern England on the back of his core campaign message that was the story of the election, securing him his robust Commons majority to begin the process of getting Brexit done.It was interesting to see in the final few days of the campaign as the polls narrowed sharply that nerves began to jangle at Tory HQ.The Prime Minister and his colleagues hurriedly issued warnings against complacency that the blue surge might not happen that just as with Theresa May in  Labourrsquos campaign momentum would peak just at the right moment, delivering humiliation to the incumbent.But the wake-up call worked , indeed, it was ever needed. A Commons majority of , much bigger than the pundits had predicted, means Mr Johnson can now look over the horizon to  with relish.After the exit poll pointed to an even healthier -seat majority for the Tories, doubts that it could be anywhere near so high were quickly banished when the result in the Labour heartland of Blyth Valley dropped the seat in the former mining community had fallen to the Toriesrsquo Ian Levy by  votes.But this was the first of many upsets as brick by brick Labourrsquos red wall was dismantled.Seats like Bassetlaw, Great Grimsby and Dudley North all saw double-digit swings away from Labour to the Tories while other heartland seats like Leigh near Manchester as well as Wakefield and Don Valley in Yorkshire, represented by Labour for decades, fell to the blue Brexit surge.As did Rother Valley, which had been represented by a Labour as far back as .But there was more humiliation for Jeremy Corbyn and his hard Left adherents. Bolsover, represented for  years by its very own ldquobeast, Dennis Skinner, and West Bromwich East, until recently the seat of Tom Watson, now ex of the Labour Party, fell.And perhaps even more symbolic was the seat of former premier and three-time Labour election winner Tony Blair, Sedgefield, succumbing to the Tories with a , majority.Alan Johnson, the former Home Secretary, told ITV News Labours huge losses were down to a "culture of betrayal" against the working class community."I dont live in London, I live in Yorkshire, a working class community. Corbyn was a disaster on the doorstep. Everyone knew that he couldnt lead the working class out of a paper bag," declared the former Hull MP.After the result emerged Michael Gove, the critic-turned-cheerleader for Mr Johnson, sought to cheerfully underscore the Toriesrsquo achievement by noting how "both the Durham Miners Gala and the Notting Hill Carnival will take place in seats held by Conservatives".Of course, with all those northern working class seats Mr Johnson has a new responsibility indeed, the once liberal Conservative Party under David Cameron has become something dferent: a blue-collar Conservative Party with a strong northern England accent.Indeed, in both his dawn rally speech and his victory address from outside No , the Tory leader acknowledged this.He said: ldquoIn this moment of national resolution I want to speak directly to those who made it possible and to all those who voted for us, for the first time, all those whose pencils may have wavered over the ballot and who heard the voices of their parents and their grandparents whispering anxiously in their ears.ldquoI say thank you for the trust you have placed in us and in me and we will work round the clock to repay your trust and to deliver on your priorities with a parliament that works for you.After the result of the  EU referendum, which took Westminster by surprise, Dominic Cummings, the PMrsquos chief aide, suggested the same ignorance by the denizens of SW was on display.Characteristically frank, he noted: "After the shock of the referendum MPs and journalists should have taken a deep breath and had a lot of self-reflection of why they misunderstood what was going on in the country.ldquoBut instead a lot of people just doubled down on their own ideas and f****d it up even more. Thats why something like this happens against expectations.

title: tom-gordon-sturgeons-mandate-built-questionable-foundations
story: It has been ldquorenewed, refreshed, and strengthened she said. But has it The SNPrsquos manesto was certainly straight-forward on the point.ldquoA vote for the SNP in this election is a vote to endorse the following proposition: it must be for the Scottish Parliament not Westminster to decide when an independence referendum should be held and the SNP intends that it will be in .Launching the manesto last month, the First Minister also said an SNP win would be a ldquoclear instruction to get on and hold the vote next year.Her partyrsquos gains on that basis, and the Scottish Toriesrsquo losses on an equally direct ldquoNo to Indyref , suggest it ought to be cut and dried.However, although the SNP undoubtedly has momentum on Indyref, the existence of a mandate is not so simple, given Ms Sturgeon has built it on rickety foundations.The language she used in the early hours of Friday morningwas telling.She did not say theelection hadgenerated a mandate from scratch.Rather, she said it had "renewed, refreshed, and strengthened a mandate that already existed, and thats the snag.The First Ministerhas consistently identied the  Scottish election as the source of her mandate, arguing it has been raised to ever greater levels of awesomeness through successive elections and votes in Holyrood.For a while, in response to Theresa May saying now was not the time for Indyref, the First Minister said her mandate was ldquocast-iron.Then, in , she said the SNP winning most Scottish seats would upgrade to a ldquotriple-lock version. This weekrsquos win is the latest tier of the tower.But it isall constructed on a muddled,mongrelmandate.True, the SNP and Scottish Greens won a majority of Holyrood seats in .But their MSPs were elected on very dferent manestos when it came to independence.In the wake of the No vote just  months previously, both parties felt obliged to tiptoe round the issue.To avoid being accused of ignoring the publicrsquos will, they resorted to tortured formulations that have undermined the notion of a clear mandate ever since.In the  Scottish election, the SNP had been clear and upfront.ldquoWe will give Scots the opportunity to decide our nationrsquos future in an independence referendum, said the manesto on which they won an absolute majority, triggering the referendum of .But in , that straightforward pitch was rewritten and made contingent on other events.The manesto position became a statement that Holyrood ldquoshould have the right to hold another referendumthere is clear and sustained evidence that independence has become the preferred option of a majority of the Scottish people - orthere is a signicant and material change in the circumstances that prevailed in , such as Scotland being taken out of the EU against our will.Despite Ms Sturgeonrsquos subsequent elevation of it, at the time this was essentially a box-ticking exercise. Like most of the country, the SNP did not believe Brexit would happen. It famously spent less money campaigning to stay in the EU than it did on a byelection in Glenrothes.However, as the main party of independence, it had to refer to a referendum somehow.So it arrived at a baroque, Brexit-related form of words that held out the possibility of independence, albeit in what it then considered highly improbable circumstances.The SNP then went backwards in . Although its constituency vote share rose .%, their regional share fell .%, and they fell from  MSPs to , losing their overall majority.A rum sort of basis for a mandate.Meanwhile, the Scottish Greens went off on their own tangent.Their  manesto had touted ldquoa multi-option referendum with choices including the status quo, a stronger Scottish Parliament with powers defined through a participative process, and full independence based on a written constitution.But by September , the Greens said the timing of Indyref, should no longer be the plaything of politicians.Instead it ldquoshould be determined by public appetitehellip For example, a call for a referendum signed by up to m people on the electoral register.Thus their  manesto said: ldquoIf a new referendum is to happen, it should come about by the will of the people, and not be driven by calculations of party political advantage. In such a referendum the Scottish Greens will campaign for independence.But there was never a petition.All of which gives Boris Johnson enough room to contest the validity of Ms Sturgeonrsquos mandate, at least until the  election comes round. At which point she may well win a mandate that cannot be gainsaid.

title: blame-games-begins-labour-party-begins-look-beyond-jeremy-corbyn-era
story: Rancour and recriminations started to break out in Labour ranks even before the vast majority of results were actually announced.Gareth Snell, fighting to hold onto Stoke-on-Trent Central, predicted he had lost his seat ahead of the constituencyrsquos result being confirmed and just minutes after the exit poll giving Boris Johnson an -majority was announced."This is one of the worst results the Labour Party could ever have imagined," declared the disgruntled candidate.ldquoThe damage and the untold horrors the Tories will unleash in Stoke-on-Trent lies firmly at the door of those running the national partys campaign and the decisions they have made about where to target and the sort of Brexit response they should have."Askedit was time for Jeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell to go, he replied tersely: ldquoYes."The fact his colleague Ruth Smeeth lost her Stoke-on-Trent North seat and Tory Jack Brereton held onto Stoke-on-Trent South meant Labour was wiped out in the Potteries.As the ballots continued to be counted, Ms Smeeth was equally critical of the party leadership, insisting: "This is a disaster. Jeremy Corbyn should resign now before his own count is in."Ian Murray, once again Labourrsquos only surviving Scottish MP, had a blunt warning for his comrades, saying: ldquoThis party must listen, this party must respond or this party will die.An arch-critic of Mr Corbyn, he attacked his party leader for helping to deliver into power "the worst Conservative Prime Minister in history".Not mincing his words, the Edinburgh South MP claimed Labour had been unable to form a ldquocredible Opposition, never mind a credible alternative government" and in a direct message to his party leader said: ldquoFor the sake of the Labour movement, for the sake of the Labour Party but more importantly for the sake of the country, not only does the person have to go but the policy and the ideology has to go as well."However, Mr Corbyn resisted calls for him depart immediately, explaining a decision on his departure would be taken after a ldquoprocess of reflection, possibly even as late as the spring.He explained: "The National Executive will have to meet, of course, in the very near future and it is up to them. It will be in the early part of next year."The Labour leader appeared to lay the complete blame for his partyrsquos woeful performance ndash the worst since  ndash not on his leadership but on Brexit. Any apology or acknowledgement of personal failure was conspicuous by its absence.He said: "I have pride in our manesto we put forward and all the policies, which actually had huge public support."But this election was taken over, ultimately, by Brexit and we as a party represent people who voted both Remain and Leave."My whole strategy was to reach out beyond the Brexit ide to try and bring people together, because ultimately the country has to come together."When askedCorbynism was dead, Mr Corbyn replied: "Theres no such thing as Corbynism. There is socialism, there is social justice, there are radical manestos, all of which are there."He added: "I dont think they are unelectable at all."The Labour leaderrsquos allies echoed the point that his leadership was not the issue, saying the defeat was down to the inability to overcome dferences over Brexit rather than a rejection of Mr Corbyns radical left-wing policy programme.But an Opinium post-poll survey of more than , people on Friday suggested the reason why voters rejected Labour were its leadership -  per cent - its stance on Brexit -  per cent - and its economic policies -  per cent.Dame Margaret Hodge, re-elected in Barking and Dagenham, who clashed forcefully with the party leader over the anti-Semitism row, tweeted: "Corbyn talking about a period of reflection. Ive reflected. You failed. Please stand down."The veteran backbencher claimed that because anti-Jewish hatred had been allowed to flourish within Labour, it had become the "nasty party" under Mr Corbynrsquos leadership.She was not alone in her call for his immediate departure.Lord Blunkett, the former Home Secretary, told the BBC: "Jeremy should go now. There should be an interim leader agreed between the National Executive and the parliamentary party perhaps somebody like Hilary Benn."It would really helpthe clique that runs the Labour Party at the moment just said sorry. I havent heard one of them apologise to all those who lost their seats last night," the Labour peer stressed.Mr Benn argued that voters simply did not have confidence in Mr Corbyns leadership."Any Labour canvasser will tell you we knocked on too many doors where people said: Ive voted Labour all my le but Im not going to vote Labour on this occasion, and they didnt have confidence in the leadership of the party."Phil Wilson, who lost Tony Blairs former seat of Sedgefield to the Tories, said attempts by the leadership to put the result down to Brexit was "mendacious nonsense"."Jeremy Corbyns leadership was a bigger problem. To say otherwise is delusional. The partys leadership went down like a lead balloon on the doorstep," he claimed.Now, Labour faces not only an examination of where it all went wrong but also a contest to succeed Mr Corbyn.The early runners and riders are thought to include: Keir Starmer, the Shadow Brexit Secretary Emily Thornberry, the Shadow Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper, the former Shadow Home Secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey, the Shadow Business Secretary, and Angela Rayner, the Shadow Education Secretary.John McDonnell, the Shadow Chancellor, tipped by some as a potential successor to Mr Corbyn, swtly ruled himself out. However, given the membership now decides who the leader is, then it is likely that whoever succeeds the current party leader will be a Corbynite which would rule out Ms Cooper and probably Sir Keir.Last night, Richard Leonard, the Scottish Labour leader, insisted the party had to ldquolisten and rebuild after a devastating result.But after the  Labour landslide Tory leader William Hague embarked on a ldquolistening tour to understand why the voters had rejected his party so comprehensively. The listening, however, was not to the British people but Conservative grassroots, who effectively reinforced the view that there was nothing wrong with the partyrsquos policies they were simply not sold hard enough to an uncomprehending public.If Labour does the same, then it, like the Tories in  will be out of power for at least a decade or more.Last night, a rumour was doing the rounds at Westminster Boris Johnson would on Saturday venture to northern England to make a speech, underpinning his commitment to his new blue-collar constituency in what were former Labour heartlands.As the Oppositionrsquos soul-searching began, so too did the process for the bruised Liberal Democrats, whose own poor performance was encapsulated by the loss of their leader Jo Swinson. For the second time in four years, the Scot became the victim of an SNP surge.In her farewell address, Ms Swinson said she had been "devastated" by the election results, in which her party took just  seats, down by one on the partys  showing at the polls.But she insisted she did not "regret trying" to be the "unapologetic voice of Remain" and "giving people the chance to choose to stop Brexit".And yet it may well be the Lib Dem leadershiprsquos decision to aclaim it could go from  seats to  seats in one giant leap to form a majority government and bscrap Brexit altogether without another referendum put many voters off.Ms Swinson and her advisers had been warned at the partyrsquos autumn party conference from grandees like Simon Hughes and Norman Lamb that backing a policy to revoke Article  was a bad move it would push the centrist Lib Dems to an extreme position a mirror image of Nigel Faragersquos Brexit Party.Even at the launch of the partyrsquos manesto in Camden, the leader began to row back on the prospect of a Lib Dem Government, lowering her sights to simply stopping the Conservatives getting a majority.And she later had to admit as the polls for her party went south, that the idea of her entering No  was ldquovery unlikely. Hubris, as always, was followed by nemesis.And so, like Labour, it looks like it will take many years for the Lib Dems to claw their way back to anything like the number of MPs they had under Paddy Ashdown, Charles Kennedy or Nick Clegg.All the zealous converts, Chuka Ummuna, Sam Gyimah and Luciana Berger failed to secure seats under the orange banner.With Ms Swinsonrsquos departure, Ed Davey, the deputy leader, and party President, Baroness Brinton, were quickly installed as their partyrsquos joint acting leaders.Interestingly, in her valedictory speech Ms Swinson name-checked all the partyrsquos experienced female MPs as possible successors: Sarah Olney Wera Hobhouse Christine Jardine and Layla Moran.ldquoWe will reflect, regroup and refresh," declared the former party leader.Having seen a Brexit-backing Conservative Party and the Scottish Nationalists make gains at the election, she warned of a "resurgent Nationalism" in the country and urged the party to "foster hope".She added: "All of us who share an alternative vision for society have a responsibility to learn from these results and find new answers. Next week, is the shortest day we will see more light in the future."The late Charles Kennedy once said the essential quality of being a Liberal Democrat was to have eternal optimism.

title: scrap-voting-system-demand-1-5m-scots-votes-wasted
story: The Electoral Reform Societyfound .% of votes did not go towards electing an MP under Westminsters first-past-the-postsystem.It has launched a petition to scrap the electoral system saying it remains unfair and does not produce a Parliament that is representative of the people.It says it is time there was a proportional system for Westminster elections, similar to the one used at Holyrood.:Boris Johnson voices fresh opposition to indyref in phone call with Nicola SturgeonBoris Johnson swept to power based on a % increase in the popular vote compared to whenTheresa May fought the  election.That % produce  more MPs for the Conservatives in Thursdays vote.The result was described by the ERS as "warped" and gave the Conservative Party an  seat majority under the UKs FPTP system of electing MPs.The Liberal Democrats, gained % on , but actually lost a seat. Labourrsquos vote fell by .% while their share of seats fell by slightly more than that at .%. And the SNP had .% of seats on .% of the UK vote.FPTP is widely criticised for producing levels of representation that are highly disproportionate, leaving the majority of society unhappy with the outcome of the election.Under FPTP, voters opt for one of the candidates listed on the ballot paper and the personwith the most votes wins. All other votes are disregarded.Complaints about Parliament being unrepresentative of the people surfaced frequently during the long-running debates on how,or when Britain should exit the EU.According to the ERS the.m "wasted" Scottish votes represented .% of those that made their choice at the ballot box on Thursday.Across the UK the ERS calculated there were ,, wasted votes, .% of those cast.  This does not take into account those who did not vote or abstained, which made up around one in three of the UK public.:Defeated Tories cant stand in way of Indyref, says Nicola SturgeonAccording to ERS, who want a "fairer" proportional representation method of electing MPs, it took on average just , votes to elect each SNP MP, but , votes to elect the lone Green MP.While it took , votes to elect each Tory MP, each Liberal Democrat required , votes, and each Labour MP , votes.Darren Hughes, chief executive of the Electoral Reform Society, said: ldquoWhen millions of voters are totally unrepresented, something has gone badly wrong. These warped results are hard-wired into Westminsterrsquos winner-takes-all voting system.ldquoItrsquos a stark reality that the majority of people did not vote for their MP. Westminsterrsquos electoral system is not just bust, it is bankrupt. First Past the Post politics has driven a coach and horses through attempts at dialogue, compromise and co-operation.ldquoWe canrsquot go on like this. Itrsquos time for Westminster to catch up with most developed democracies and back a genuinely fair, democratic politics ndash where seats match votes and all voters are heard.ldquoFirst Past the Post is forcing people to lsquohold their nosersquo every election. It is reducing choice through back-door party pacts. And it is leaving voters alienated and excluded, while warping our national debate.ldquoWe urge all parties to put principle first and bring our political system into the st century. With trust in our institutions at rock bottom, this is a vital first step to building a better politics.ERS produced a top  of the seats which required the smallest share of the vote to win. Three were seats won by the SNP, three were Labour wins and two were Conservative victories.The SNP needed just .% support to take Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath, while East Lothian needed .% backing and Dunbartonshire East was won with just .%.Sinn Fein needed just .% support for victory in Down South - the lowest level for a seat win in the election.

title: coveted-michelin-stars-not-end-all-kitchin-argues
story: Tom Kitchin, who won a Michelin star for his Edinburgh restaurant The Kitchin within months of it opening in , said such awards were important, but not ldquothe be all and end all.ldquoTherersquos no denying a Michelin star is important to chefs like myself, butyou win it you can lose it again and go back down the ladder, he said.His comments come when debate about the awards has been prompted by the continuing failure of Glasgow restaurants to win the prestigious awards for fine dining. However, Kitchin says it isnrsquot all about the haute cuisine. He more recently opened the gastropubs Scran and Scallie in Edinburgh and Gullanersquos Bonnie Badger, both of which achieved Michelinrsquos Bib Gourmand award for good food at great prices.ldquoI think the most important thing is that we are very honest in what we do and give it everything wersquove got, the Scot says. ldquoThe Scottish Restaurant scene is as strong as it has ever been and there are amazing restaurants in Glasgow and the West of Scotland. We are punching above our weight. We have the best larder in the world in Scotland, so it is really exciting but there is still a lot of work to be done.Mr Kitchin was speaking as he gave his backing to the charity Maryrsquos Meals, for its Christmas appeal in support of its work feeding more than . million children every school day in some of the worldrsquos poorest countries including Malawi, India and Haiti.The charity is hosting a virtual Christmas dinner this month, selling table settings for an online table where donors can have a place setting added in their name for pound. ndash enough to give a child a meal a day for an entire school year. So far more than , have been sold since the start of the month.The chef says hersquos inspired by the charityrsquos ability to ldquothink outside the box, having worked with them for four years now. ldquoPeople need something to grab their attention, and they certainly grabbed mine, he said. ldquoIt is a very simple concept. The children get a meal and the knock -on effect is they also get an education.Mr Kitchin says he gets asked to support lots of charities but is drawn to those supporting children. Sadly even in Scotland, schools have been used to help families feed their kids, he says, with problems such as ldquoholiday hunger increasingly recognised, he points out.ldquoWe have similar problems here in Scotland. It is brutal what happens to some kids in the holidays and Christmas really hits it all home.ldquoAt this time of year, people are getting a new box from Amazon through the door every day ndash but this Maryrsquos Meals campaign really makes you think. Just pound. feeds a child every day. Itrsquos fantastic.Daniel Adams, UK executive director of Maryrsquos Meals said: ldquoOur virtual Christmas dinner brings together people from around the globe who believe that every child deserves an education and enough to eat.ldquoThanks to the kindness of those who set a place, we can continue to reach children living in some of the worldrsquos poorest countries with our le-changing school meal, he added. ldquoI canrsquot think of a better gt to give or receive this Christmas.While hersquos conscious of child poverty at home in Scotland, Kitchin is also concerned about challenges such such as Brexit, he says, which have an impact on his supply chain and potentially his workforce. His five establishments now employ  people, which he says is a big responsibility he and his we Michaela feel keenly.ldquoWe are proud to be doing this in Scotland, he said. ldquoBut we are worried about Brexit. Costs are spiralling out of control he says. ldquoI donrsquot want to use battery chickens or farmed fish, but everything goes up in price and the customer doesnrsquot understand and doesnrsquot want to pay more, he explained.Meanwhile he also fears challenges in recruitingimmigration policies change. ldquoWe have great Scottish and British people working for us but also a large number of Europeans, Africans and people from North and South America. Our business doesnrsquot work without those people.They will be the chefs of the future, he says, instilled with the philosophy behind his award-wining restaurants and his faith in Scotlandrsquos charms.ldquoMy philosophy is when tourists come, they are going to be blown away with the scenery and the history. Butthey sleep well and eat well and drink well too that really helps. Theyrsquoll go back home and tell people lsquoI went to Scotland and it was unbelievablersquo, he said.

title: dram-history-scotched-claims-water-life-flowed-ireland
story: However, in a declaration thatrsquos enough to make you want to pour a very stf drink ndash a dram, preferably ndash our national drink has been declared as anything but.According to the makers of a new film that explores the cultural impact of whisky from its origins to modern times, whiskyrsquos Scottish roots would appear to be ever so slightly Irish.Asthat wasnrsquot enough to make whisky drinkers choke on their finest malt, therersquos even a very strong hint that our best-loved export might just have a slice of English DNA too.According to Glasgow-based whisky expert Dave Broom, who explores whiskyrsquos heritage in the film The Amber Light, and its producer Adam Park, there is ldquostrong evidence to suggest whisky may have been first developed in Ireland and brought to Islay, to be drunk at the seat of the High Kings.There, under the distilling expertise of one particular Irish family, the spirit is thought to have evolved into a tipple bearing at least a passing similarity to todayrsquos whisky.According to Mr Park, research carried out for the film suggests the Beaton family ndash Irish physicians who developed a vast international knowledge of botanical remedies ndash probably hold the key to the earliest forms of what would become the first Scotch whisky.ldquoThe Beatons were pretty amazing people, they travelled the world translating medical scripts and building their knowledge, he said.ldquoThey came to service of the High Kings and became experts in distilling spirit and added to it the plants and flowers that grew around them.The Beatons, whose family name appears as MacMeic-bethad and MacBeth, are thought to have arrived on Islay in the th century at the time of the marriage between Aine OrsquoCathain and Angus Og MacDonald, Lord Of The Isles.While there is no clear documentation to conclusively link the family to the origins of whisky, there are said to be clear signs their skills were almost certainly involved.Mr Park added: ldquoIt gets murky and therersquos not an accepted history of how whisky came about, but the best guess is the Beatons came to Islay when it was the seat of the High Kings who ruled huge parts of Scotland and Ireland.However, research for the film led to another twist: the English were probably already creating their own form of a dram at about the same time.Speaking to the , Mr Broom said: ldquoIf you look at the north of Ireland and across to Islay, thatrsquos the cradle of distillationhellip but the first record I found is in Chaucerrsquos Canterbury Tales.The Beaton family became hereditary physicians to the Scottish crown, serving Robert The Bruce and every subsequent Scottish king, while also providing medical knowledge to clan chiefs from the Western Isles to the Lowlands.They were known to make use of medicinal plants and traditional therapies at a time when others relied on superstition and myths as often ill-fated cures for illnesses and injuries.As word spread of their comforting drink, whisky stills spread across Scotland.Scotch whisky was first recorded on the Exchequer Rolls in  when a friar called John Cor, distiller at Lindores Abbey in Newburgh, Fe, and servant to the court of James IV, was noted to have made ldquoaqua vitae, VIII bolls of malt.While the Beatonrsquos fellow countrymen pursued distilling their own Irish whiskey, Mr Park says Scotsrsquo ingenious methods of circumventing taxes and American prohibition laws ndash when Scotch was allowed as a ldquomedicinal product ndash helped embed whisky as the premium spirit.Later, shrewd marketing practices with their focus on Highland history and heritage, saw whisky overwhelm its Irish and American cousins and lay foundations for todayrsquos pound. billion export market.The film, which is currently touring cinemas across the country, also explores how whisky has become embedded in Scottish culture yet is constantly evolving to attract new generations of drinkers.That, he adds, includes cocktails and mixers that shatter whiskyrsquos traditional ldquogentleman in tweeds image ndash such as Lagavulin mixed with Coke, dubbed a Smokey Cokey.ldquoLike any commercial enterprise, whisky needs to attract new customers, says Mr Park. ldquoThe image of the stuffy old man in a leather armchair in the library having an undiluted single malt is still there, but itrsquos also not there.A spokesman for the Scotch Whisky Association said: ldquoThe earliest known record of Scotch Whisky production dates from the Exchequer Rolls of , but it is likely the lsquoAqua Vitaersquo was being produced long before this date.ldquoIt is likely early development of distillation in Scotland and Ireland took place in parallel, ultimately leading to two distinct global industries.Details of screenings of The Amber Light can be found at: www.amberlightfilm

title: general-election-2019-turnout-won-snp
story: At that point, with the polls positive but the Scottish Tories looking tougher to remove than expected, the party was simply anxious to break the psychological threshold of  MPs.Anything below that was seen as depressingly lukewarm, hardly the springboard to another independence referendum Ms Sturgeon needed.In the closing week, the party revised down its expectations. Canvassers reported the Tory vote was holding up and suddenly just two or three gains on top of the  seats won in  became the projection.Strategists discounted taking Jo Swinsonrsquos Dunbartonshire East seat, for instance, reckoning decapitating the LibDems, while enjoyable, was an ask too far.The BBCrsquos exit poll with its prediction of  seats was therefore met with extreme scepticism.The FMrsquos aide sent a one-word text to those asking about it: ldquob****cks. But after a round of frantic phone calls to activists and organisers on the ground, slowly the picture at SNP HQ began to change.One of the key factors was turnout. ldquoThatrsquos what we underestimated, said a source.ldquoWe knew our vote was motivated, but turnout was still better than we expected.While turnout was down in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, it was up in Scotland, rising . points to . per cent. Across the UK it fell . points to .%.The SNPrsquos final tally of  MPs ndash actually  plus one suspended member who still appeared on the ballot as SNP ndash was therefore far better than Ms Sturgeon had hoped.She immediately put it to use, declaring it was a renewed, refreshed and strengthened mandate for holding Indyref in . The SNP improved on every metric.Besides gaining  seats, the party increased its share of the vote from . to %, and gained , votes, with a total of .m.It was a victory made all the sweeter by reversals for the party most opposed to Indyref.The Scottish Tories had also misread their data and had over-estimated their support rather than under-estimating it.They lost seven of their  MPs, and saw their vote share fall from . to .%.Their vote total fell , to ,. Yet, on the eve of polling, the party had been confidently talking up gains to the media.At a joint event with her successor Jackson Carlaw, former leader Ruth Davidson had said she wanted to see her party take seats off the SNP.ldquoIrsquove not just been spending time in the seats that we hold trying to defend them, Irsquove been spending time in seats that wersquore trying to take, she said.In the end, the party went backwards in  of its  seats.The Tories did better on the offensive, increasing their vote in Lanark  Hamilton East, Ayrshire Central and Argyll  Bute, but by small or pitul amounts.They slumped in the ultra-marginal target of Perth  North Perthshire, where the SNPrsquos Pete Wishart had a majority of . He was ed with a majority of ,.The SNP increased their vote across the board.It was a stark contrast to , when Scotland had been the one bright spot for the Tories.Then, Scotland had been the only source of Tory gains, as the party under Ms Davidson picked up  seats and gaveTheresa May the numbers she needed to stay in power. The partyrsquos vote share increased by .%, double the rise across the UK.But at this election, Scotland provided the worst Tory result. The only nation in which the party lost MPs or vote share was Scotland.The Scottish campaign was based on making Ms Sturgeon and the SNP synonymous with Indyref in the belief Labour voters would vote tactically to protect the Union.But it turned out Labour voters preferred voting tactically to help the SNP get rid of Tories.The party knew Boris Johnson and Brexit werenrsquot going down well ndash they latterly airbrushed the PM out of their campaign ndash but thought Ms Sturgeon was even less popular.Their own animosity to ldquothat effing woman proved a blindspot. A big headache for the Scottish Tories is that this election was supposed to be the prelude to their Holyrood campaign of .The party was hoping to build up support and convert it into gains on the regional lists. Butit starts losing constituencies, those MSPs will wash up on the list as consolation wins under the proportional voting system and make net gains will be harder.One bleak omen for Mr Carlaw is that the Tory share of the vote fell almost  points in avowedly Remain East Renfrewshire, while the SNPrsquos rose . points. Now a born-again Leaver, Mr Carlaw represents the equivalent seat at Holyrood.A similar swing to the SNP in  would overturn his ,-vote majority, sending him back to the West of Scotland list. The one possible upside for the Scottish Tories is the election may lead to an injection of new blood at Holyrood, as defeated MPs look to Edinburgh for a new berth, clearing out some of the dead timber.Butthe results were bad for the Tories and their campaign against Indyref, they were truly atrocious for Scottish Labour. Despite its precarious hold on the electoral map ndash four of the seven seats it was defending had majorities below , ndash the party was predicting it wouldnine MPs just hours before the polls closed.It was over-confidence based on positive canvas s. In Glasgow North East, Paul Sweeney publicly predicted he would increase his -vote majority on the back of glowing canvas data.After the massive YouGov poll on Tuesday predicting a Tory landslide, the partyrsquos digital chief Aidan Kerr tweeted: ldquoGlasgow North East is not going to the SNP. Andthe pollsters think this, then God knows what  they have got wrong.Mr Sweeney lost to the SNPrsquos Anne McLaughlin by , votes. It was a profound failure of the party machine that points to deep, systemic problems. The party reckoned it was making a comeback in its old heartlands of Glasgow and North Lanarkshire.But when the results came in, Labour lost vote share in every Glasgow seat and in all its North Lanarkshire targets as well. In fact, Labour lost a bigger slice of its vote share in Scotland than anywhere  in the UK, down . points to a wretched .%, thanks to the loss of , votes.Its sole MP north of the Border is Ian Murray in Edinburgh South, who did not hesitate to blame Mr Corbyn for the partyrsquos desperate decline. Mr Leonard has now lost two elections in a year.Last night he vowed to lead his party into the  election as well. His opponents will be chuffed.The LibDems, despite losing Ms Swinson, were the steadiest party of the night. It gained North East Fe to stay on four MPs, increasing its share of the vote by . points.The upshot of it all is Ms Sturgeon will ramp up demands for Indyref. Mr Johnson called her last night to get his refusal in early. Because whatrsquos in it for him  If he granted a Section  order, despite his ldquoguarantee not do so, it would cause turmoil in his party.He also knows referendums bring down leaders. Ask David Cameron, Theresa May and Alex Salmond. Mr Johnson has no appetite to bring his premiership to an early end by granting and then losing Indyref.Perhaps most compelling for a politician who seems to care for little but himself, defeat would mean going down in the history books as the last Prime Minister of the UK, the man who made himself Minister for the Union then oversaw its break-up. It is not a legacy he would savour.

title: aberdeenshire council ensures a clear route for voters
story: Final preparations are being made by Aberdeenshire Council to ensure voters have a clear route as they head for the polls later this week.With the General Election taking place on Thursdaythe Roads, Landscape and Waste Service has been reviewing its winter service arrangements and preparing a contingency plan which can be implemented in the event of severe weather occurring in the days before or during polling day.The service has been working closely with the council’s election team in the preparation of the plan which includes scenario planning for dferent levels of severe weather events, how that might impact on access to polling stations and what resources would be required in order to respond to severe weather.At this time, no specic information has been issued by the Met Office suggesting particularly severe weather, with Wednesday forecast to be largely dry with some light snow on very high ground from noon on Thursday through to midnight. However, forecasts will be reviewed daily over the next few days as we approach polling day.The council’s Roads and Landscape Services manager Derek Murray said: “Should we be in a period of severe weather on the day of the election one of key tasks for the Roads, Landscape and Waste Service will be to ensure that the electorate can access all the polling stations on roads that are as safe as reasonably possible throughout polling day.“The service has placed additional resources on stand-by on December - to ensure that the maximum available staff, plant and equipment can respond where necessary.”The location of each polling station has been carefully considered and road and footway treatments routes in the vicinity have been adjusted to suit as necessary.Car parks at or near polling stations will also be treated where possible and bagged salt has been provided to every polling station for use around access doors and paths.The council’s list of farmers and contractors are also being contacted so that the council is in the best possible position to respond to severe weather.Meanwhile, normal operating hours for the council’s gritting crews between .am and pm may be extended to ensure polling stations can be accessed safely between am and pm and in order that ballot boxes can be safely delivered to the count in Aberdeen after the polls close.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"If you have fancied trying indoor rock climbing why not Gie it a Go "  "Gie it a Go" this Christmas viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: finish line for ultramarathon man
story: An Insch man has completed his epic #Running Home # adventure of running  ultramarathons throughout this year.Dr Mark Calder has covered , miles, tracing pilgrim routes across Scotland and Northern England.His tremendous effort is to raise money for a project run by Embrace the Middle East, which supports refugees tohome and rebuild their lives in war-torn Iraq. Dr Calder’s final run took place on Saturday, November .Covering  miles he ran from South Queensferry, Edinburgh to St Andrews via the Fe Pilgrim Way.The run also marked the feast day of the th Century Queen who opened up the ferry route for pilgrims to St Andrews between South and North Queensferry.The distances of the runs have ranged infrom  miles to  miles, with some spanning over a number of days. This has been a gruelling challenge for Dr Calder who usually ides his time between working for Embrace the Middle East and teaching at Durham universities. He said: “There have been some real struggles this year, running ultramarathons teaches you a huge amount. “Running through the day into the night against a headwind, the physical pain or when it’s rained for days can really sap your mood, it’s intense on an emotional and mental level it’s during these times that make me reflect on what I’m doing and why.” Based near Aberdeen, Dr Calder is a husband and father of two with a lelong interest in the Middle East. Having completed a PhD specialising on the region and spent  months living in Palestine, he now works for Embrace the Middle East.He continued: “ I’ve learned a huge amount from the challenges I’ve faced and have felt encouraged by people’s support and engagement with the project.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The winning S team from Kemnay Academy"  Schools set for competition finals viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"“With their support, I’ve been running in pursuit of a happier ending to a long, unhappy story in Iraq. story: An Inverurie youngster was welcomed onto the site of the new #m Inverurie Community Campus recently to enjoy a work experience day.Jack McCranorfrom St Andrew’s School took part in the work experience day after receiving an invitation from the executive chairman of Robertson Group, Bill Robertson.Jack recently met the chairman and First Minister Nicola Sturgeon MSP during a tour of the new facility and expressed his interest in learning more about modern construction.Since then, Bill Robertson and the team at Inverurie Community Campus were delighted to organise this unique opportunity for Jack so he could learn and experience how his own new school and the other community facilities are coming together, ahead of their opening in spring .Jack – who has a keen interest in construction and practical school work- learned about the modern construction methods being used by Robertson on the new Inverurie Community Campus project.He also had an opportunity to see ongoing work up-close and even took a ride around the site in a tipper lorry.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Paulwith the Scottish War Blinded group and RAF Lossiemouth personnel "   with the Scottish War Blinded group and RAF Lossiemouth personnel "  th birthday for war veteran viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: schools set for competition finals
story: Teams from  secondary schools around the North-east have competed in the final heats of a new construction challenge.The ‘Build Your Future’ challenge was launched by Grampian Construction Trainingin August of this year and was designed to highlight the full range of exciting, inspiring and rewarding career choices within the construction industry to pupils, parents and teachers.The event very quickly gathered widespread support from ious groups, businesses and educational establishments including Stewart Milne Group, Robert Gordon University, North East of Scotland Colleges and Kirkwood Homes.Collectively, supporting companies created a range of inspiring construction-based tasks including ‘Build a Sustainable City’, ‘Create a Lock Block Driveway’, ‘Plumbing Obstacle Course’, ‘Build a Structure Without Using Your Hands’, and ‘Build a Tower, on Time and Under Budget’.Teams had a maximum of  minutes to complete each challenge and were marked on criteria such as how well they worked together, and their overall understanding of what was expected of them.Teams of ten S pupils from Meldrum Academy, Ellon Academy and Kemnay Academy took part in the event on Thursday, November  and will go through to the final challenge at Aberdeen Football Club on Thursday, January .The overall winner will be presented with their award by special guest Stewart Milne, who will have the chance to share his own career path with the pupils.Jim Buchan, Chair of Grampian Construction Training said: “We are absolutely delighted at how well the Build Your Future challenge has been embraced.“ We would like to take this opportunity to thank every school who signed up to take part in this first year, ensuring that the challenge got off to the best possible start.“We have met over  incredible young people and it has been wonderful to see how they tackled and embraced each of the challenges. I would also like to congratulate those who have made it to the final, we look forward to seeing them all again at Aberdeen Football Club in January.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"No matter what the weather, Aberdeenshire Council will being doing its best to ensure your path to the polling station is clear." title: water treatment works opened
story: A # million state-of-the-art waste water treatment works which has the potential to reduce the amount of energy used during the treatment process by half has officially opened in Inverurie.The new works, which is the first in Scotland to make use of an innovative technology called Nereda, was opened by Minister for Rural Affairs and the Natural Environment Mairi Gougeon on Friday, December .The award-winning technology breaks sludge into granules, the structure of which enable multiple treatment processes to take place simultaneously .This and the granules’ faster settlement make treating waste water signicantly faster and more efficient, while avoiding the need for pumps and mixers. It means less energy and less space is needed to treat a higher quantity of waste water, reducing the operating costs of the site. It also removes the need to chemically treat the effluent, increasing the protection of the rivers Don and Urie, and provides the capacity to support the local community as it continues to grow and flourish. The project was delivered by Scottish Water alliance partner ESD and included building new sewer pipework, improving the resilience of the site to flooding and upgrading existing equipment. Ms Gougeon said: “While treating waste water isn’t something people probably like to think about too often, it is something that is absolutely vital to protect not only our health and sanitation, but also the environment. “Developing new, more efficient ways of treating waste water through the deployment of new technology, is hugely important as Scotland takes decisive steps towards tackling the climate emergency we are facing around the world.” Chief Executive of Scottish Water Douglas Millican said: “We are always looking for ways to innovate and protect the environment both locally and globally, so it is very exciting to see this new state-of-the-art treatment works officially opened here in Inverurie – the first of its kind in Scotland. “Not only does it mean we can continue to treat waste water effectively and protect the environment for years to come, it also underlines our commitment to pursue new ways to lower our energy requirements, towards reaching our ambitious goal of achieving net zero emissions by .” Most construction work on site was completed in the Spring and the new treatment process has since been closely monitored during commissioning and beyond.While most of the work took place within the established Scottish Water site, installation of new pipework beneath the railway line involved a closure to Keithhall Road which was completed ahead of schedule in April .data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! As well as delivering the long-term benefits of the investment for the future of the town and its environment, we have worked to minimise any short-term disruption for the neighbours of the site and to make a positive contribution to the le of the local community.“We are very grateful for the welcome we’ve been given and for residents’ support and understanding while construction was underway.”

title: wee sleep out at logie durno school
story: Pupils and staff at Logie Durno Primary School took part in a sleep out to raise awareness of homelessness.The school held its ‘Wee Sleep Out’ on Thursday, December  - the day before the international ‘World’s Big Sleep Out’ day.Head teacher Elizabeth McMahon said: “The event went really well, I was bowled over as all but two of our pupils took part, it was absolutely fantastic.“The pupils made a ten minute film focusing on the matter of homelessness so they are really clued up with why we decided to do this.“The matter was quite new and challenging for them as they weren’t aware of it before but now they are keen to help and make a dference.“We raised nearly £, which is really incredible as we are a small school of just  pupils.”She added: “I am ever so proud of the children.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Jack McCranor during his work experience day at the new Inverurie Community Campus site"  Jack enjoys work experience day viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"
